conclusion: Determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground.
The basketball is dropped from rest at a height H.
It falls under the influence of gravity and air resistance.
The gravitational force is mg and the air resistance is λmg.
The effective acceleration a_eff is given by a_eff = g(1 + λ).
Using the kinematic equation for motion under constant acceleration, the velocity just before hitting the ground v_1 is v_1 = √(2gH).
The basketball rebounds to a height h.
The velocity just after the collision v_2 can be related to the rebound height h using v_2 = √(2gh).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is given by e = v_2/v_1.
Substituting the expressions for v_1 and v_2, e = √(h/H).
The air resistance affects the energy loss during the motion.
The condition 0 < λ < (H-h)/(H+h) ensures that the air resistance is not too large.
Since the ratio e is derived from the heights H and h, it inherently accounts for the energy loss due to air resistance.
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity of the basketball during its collision with the ground is e = √(h/H).
